quiz.title: Physics Grade 11: Latent Heat
quiz.subtitle: Unit 7, Quiz 7: Phase Changes & Energy Calculations
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: What happens to the temperature of a 1kg block of ice while it is actively melting at 0°C?
options: It stays constant at 0°C until all ice has melted.
It increases steadily as heat is absorbed.
It decreases due to the cooling effect of the water.
It fluctuates depending on the heat source.
questions.explanation: During a phase change, the heat energy added goes into breaking intermolecular bonds (potential energy) rather than increasing molecular speed (kinetic energy/temperature).

questions.question: How much energy is required to melt 2.0 kg of ice at 0°C? (Lf = 3.34 x 10^5 J/kg)
Why is the Latent Heat of Vaporization (Lv) for water significantly higher than the Latent Heat of Fusion (Lf)?
options: It takes more energy to fully separate molecules into a gas than to loosen them into a liquid.
Gases are always hotter than liquids.
Water molecules are heavier in the gas phase.
Steam has a higher specific heat capacity than ice.
questions.explanation: Vaporization requires breaking all remaining intermolecular attractions to turn the liquid into a gas, which is more energy-intensive than slightly shifting a lattice to melt it.

questions.question: How much energy is needed to turn 0.5 kg of liquid water at 100°C into steam at 100°C? (Lv = 2.26 x 10^6 J/kg)
A 1.0 kg block of ice at -10°C is heated until it becomes water at 10°C. How many distinct energy calculations are required to find the total heat added?
questions.explanation: Calculation 1: Heat ice from -10 to 0 (mcΔT). Calculation 2: Melt ice (mLf). Calculation 3: Heat water from 0 to 10 (mcΔT).

questions.question: Which of the following describes 'Condensation' in terms of energy?
options: Energy is released by the substance (Exothermic).
Energy is absorbed by the substance (Endothermic).
No energy is exchanged during condensation.
The substance gains temperature while condensing.
questions.explanation: Condensation is the reverse of vaporization. Since energy is required to vaporize, that same energy is released back to the environment when the gas turns back into a liquid.

questions.question: If 334,000 J of energy is removed from 1.0 kg of liquid water at 0°C, what is the final state of the substance?
options: A mixture of half ice and half water.
questions.explanation: Removing exactly Lf (3.34 x 10^5 J) results in a complete phase change from liquid to solid without decreasing the temperature.

questions.question: On a heating curve (Temperature vs. Time), what does a horizontal line represent?
options: A phase change where temperature is constant.
A period where no heat is being added.
A state where the substance is cooling down.
The substance is changing temperature rapidly.
questions.explanation: The horizontal segments (plateaus) indicate that the added heat is going into a phase change rather than increasing the temperature.

questions.question: What is the unit for Latent Heat (L)?
questions.explanation: Latent heat is energy per unit mass required for a phase change, so it is expressed in Joules per kilogram (J/kg).

questions.question: Calculate the total energy to turn 0.1 kg of ice at 0°C into water at 20°C. (Lf = 3.34x10^5, c = 4184)

scoreMessages.90: Brilliant! You've mastered the energy logic behind phase changes.
scoreMessages.70: Good job. Remember to separate the heating steps from the melting steps.
scoreMessages.50: Decent progress—try mapping out a heating curve to visualize the mcΔT and mL steps.
scoreMessages.0: Review the heating curve of water and the formula Q = mL.
